title: Hudson's Bay to axe 265 jobs in cost-cutting move
text:
Canadian retail group Hudson's Bay Co is to axe 265 jobs as part of a cost-cutting initiative designed to save the business around US$75m next year. 
The company is to realign its North American operations by establishing new 'Centres of Excellence' for its customer relationship management, creative and human resources functions, and consolidate key functions. 
Meanwhile, it will implement "substantial" technology enhancements and accelerate the consolidation to one common platform across company banners, under the leadership of newly appointed Janet Schalk as chief information officer, and Dion Rooney as executive vice president of HBC digital. 
In addition, the group will align resources in business functions to match its current and future business strategy, while investing in areas that will drive growth. The changes will result in 265 job losses at its headquarters and corporate functions, and Hudson's Bay will incur a charge of $20m in the third quarter of 2015 related to the realignment. 
Nonetheless, Hudson's Bay says the initiatives are designed to enable the business to invest greater resources in the areas of the business offering the most significant return on investment potential, while leveraging strengths across its retail banners and increasing efficiencies. 
"By enabling our teams to work smarter, faster and more effectively, we expect to achieve substantial cost savings and continue to invest in our core strategies to build our business, drive further improved financial performance and support the long-term vision of HBC,” explains CEO Jerry Storch. 
Separately, Canadian retail group Hudson's Bay has completed its EUR2.5bn (US$2.8bn) acquisition of Galeria Holding , operator of Germany’s Galeria Kaufhof department store chain and Belgium’s only department store, Galeria Inno.
